DOC.HEAD: Poland Signs Agreement to Get Millions in Western Credit
DOC.TEXT: Poland has formally agreed to overhaul its economy in exchange for $700 million in immediate credit from the International Monetary Fund and the promise of billions more in Western aid, officials said Saturday. Deputy Prime Minister Leszek Balcerowicz and the chairman of the National Bank of Poland, Wladyslaw Baka signed a letter of intent that was approved by the IMF executive board in Washington, the state news agency PAP said. The first credit installment could be received as early as next week, PAP reported. Acceptance of the letter also launches a $1 billion fund being prepared by Western countries to back the Polish currency, PAP said. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and his Council of Ministers met through the night Friday, reviewing the plan in which Poland vows to choke off 900 percent inflation, cut budget deficits and weather the unemployment and poverty that the painful economic reforms are likely to bring. The plan, negotiated since Mazowiecki formed the East bloc's first government led by non-Communists in September, is tied to the most extensive economic reform legislation ever attempted in the region. Introduced in Parliament a week ago, the program would overhaul the centralized state-run economy and replace it with a market-oriented system. The IMF agreement will certify to Western leaders that Poland is making serious efforts to put its economy in order and is expected to release further loans from the World Bank and other sources. It is also critical to arranging the rescheduling of payments on Poland's $40 billion debt to the West. ``It was signed during the night. It was important to sign it as soon as possible because the money could come pretty soon,'' said Tomasz Drzewosowski, director of the government press office. In addition to the $700 million standby loan, the IMF letter of intent is expected to lead to $300 million in World Bank loans and about $3 billion in other Western aid. The $1 billion currency stabilization fund is expected to be ready early in 1990. Poland is working to make its zloty internally convertible with the hard currencies of the West, a step important to attracting the Western business investment badly needed to replace Poland's outmoded and unproductive industries. The government has asked Parliament for speedy approval of the economic reform legislation so it can be implemented Jan. 1. Deputy Finance Minister Janusz Sawicki has said that if the IMF money were not ready by Jan. 1, several Western countries probably would offer a bridge loan until the first installment arrives. The IMF, one of the biggest lenders to Third World counties, is owned by 152 governments, with the United States holding the largest number of votes. The economic program anticipates that Poles' real income will fall 20 percent, there will be a 5 percent decrease in industrial output, and a 2 percent to 3 percent drop in the gross national product. Price increases of 25 to 50 percent a month during early 1990 are expected as enterprises raise prices to survive after losing production subsidies that have kept charges artificially low and maintained unprofitable firms. Many bankruptcies are likely. The government is planning the country's first unemployment benefits and estimates there will be 400,000 workers displaced. Under the communist system, unemployment and poverty officially did not exist and there has been no welfare structure.
